1 //===-- LoopPredication.cpp - Guard based loop predication pass -----------===// ----
2 // ----
3 // Part of the LLVM Project, under the Apache License v2.0 with LLVM Exceptions. ----
4 // See https://llvm.org/LICENSE.txt for license information. ----
5 // SPDX-License-Identifier: Apache-2.0 WITH LLVM-exception ----
6 // ----
7 //===----------------------------------------------------------------------===// ----
8 // ----
9 // The LoopPredication pass tries to convert loop variant range checks to loop ----
10 // invariant by widening checks across loop iterations. For example, it will ----
11 // convert ----
12 // ----
13 // for (i = 0; i < n; i++) { ----
14 // guard(i < len); ----
15 // ... ----
16 // } ----
17 // ----
18 // to ----
19 // ----
20 // for (i = 0; i < n; i++) { ----
21 // guard(n - 1 < len); ----
22 // ... ----
23 // } ----
24 // ----
25 // After this transformation the condition of the guard is loop invariant, so ----
26 // loop-unswitch can later unswitch the loop by this condition which basically ----
27 // predicates the loop by the widened condition: ----
28 // ----
29 // if (n - 1 < len) ----
30 // for (i = 0; i < n; i++) { ----
31 // ... ----
32 // } ----
33 // else ----
34 // deoptimize ----
35 // ----
36 // It's tempting to rely on SCEV here, but it has proven to be problematic. ----
37 // Generally the facts SCEV provides about the increment step of add ----
38 // recurrences are true if the backedge of the loop is taken, which implicitly ----
39 // assumes that the guard doesn't fail. Using these facts to optimize the ----
40 // guard results in a circular logic where the guard is optimized under the ----
41 // assumption that it never fails. ----
42 // ----
43 // For example, in the loop below the induction variable will be marked as nuw ----
44 // basing on the guard. Basing on nuw the guard predicate will be considered ----
45 // monotonic. Given a monotonic condition it's tempting to replace the induction ----
46 // variable in the condition with its value on the last iteration. But this ----
47 // transformation is not correct, e.g. e = 4, b = 5 breaks the loop. ----
48 // ----
49 // for (int i = b; i != e; i++) ----
50 // guard(i u< len) ----
51 // ----
52 // One of the ways to reason about this problem is to use an inductive proof ----
53 // approach. Given the loop: ----
54 // ----
55 // if (B(0)) { ----
56 // do { ----
57 // I = PHI(0, I.INC) ----
58 // I.INC = I + Step ----
59 // guard(G(I)); ----
60 // } while (B(I)); ----
61 // } ----
62 // ----
63 // where B(x) and G(x) are predicates that map integers to booleans, we want a ----
64 // loop invariant expression M such the following program has the same semantics ----
65 // as the above: ----
66 // ----
67 // if (B(0)) { ----
68 // do { ----
69 // I = PHI(0, I.INC) ----
70 // I.INC = I + Step ----
71 // guard(G(0) && M); ----
72 // } while (B(I)); ----
73 // } ----
74 // ----
75 // One solution for M is M = forall X . (G(X) && B(X)) => G(X + Step) ----
76 // ----
77 // Informal proof that the transformation above is correct: ----
78 // ----
79 // By the definition of guards we can rewrite the guard condition to: ----
80 // G(I) && G(0) && M ----
81 // ----
82 // Let's prove that for each iteration of the loop: ----
83 // G(0) && M => G(I) ----
84 // And the condition above can be simplified to G(Start) && M. ----
85 // ----
86 // Induction base. ----
87 // G(0) && M => G(0) ----
88 // ----
89 // Induction step. Assuming G(0) && M => G(I) on the subsequent ----
90 // iteration: ----
91 // ----
92 // B(I) is true because it's the backedge condition. ----
93 // G(I) is true because the backedge is guarded by this condition. ----
94 // ----
95 // So M = forall X . (G(X) && B(X)) => G(X + Step) implies G(I + Step). ----
96 // ----
97 // Note that we can use anything stronger than M, i.e. any condition which ----
98 // implies M. ----
99 // ----
100 // When S = 1 (i.e. forward iterating loop), the transformation is supported ----
101 // when: ----
102 // * The loop has a single latch with the condition of the form: ----
103 // B(X) = latchStart + X latchLimit, ----
104 // where is u<, u<=, s<, or s<=. ----
105 // * The guard condition is of the form ----
106 // G(X) = guardStart + X u< guardLimit ----
107 // ----
108 // For the ult latch comparison case M is: ----
109 // forall X . guardStart + X u< guardLimit && latchStart + X ----
110 // guardStart + X + 1 u< guardLimit ----
111 // ----
112 // The only way the antecedent can be true and the consequent can be false is ----
113 // if ----
114 // X == guardLimit - 1 - guardStart ----
115 // (and guardLimit is non-zero, but we won't use this latter fact). ----
116 // If X == guardLimit - 1 - guardStart then the second half of the antecedent is ----
117 // latchStart + guardLimit - 1 - guardStart u< latchLimit ----
118 // and its negation is ----
119 // latchStart + guardLimit - 1 - guardStart u>= latchLimit ----
120 // ----
121 // In other words, if ----
122 // latchLimit u<= latchStart + guardLimit - 1 - guardStart ----
123 // then: ----
124 // (the ranges below are written in ConstantRange notation, where [A, B) is the ----
125 // set for (I = A; I != B; I++ /*maywrap*/) yield(I);) ----
126 // ----
127 // forall X . guardStart + X u< guardLimit && ----
128 // latchStart + X u< latchLimit => ----
129 // guardStart + X + 1 u< guardLimit ----
130 // == forall X . guardStart + X u< guardLimit && ----
131 // latchStart + X u< latchStart + guardLimit - 1 - guardStart => ----
132 // guardStart + X + 1 u< guardLimit ----
133 // == forall X . (guardStart + X) in [0, guardLimit) && ----
134 // (latchStart + X) in [0, latchStart + guardLimit - 1 - guardStart) => ----
135 // (guardStart + X + 1) in [0, guardLimit) ----
136 // == forall X . X in [-guardStart, guardLimit - guardStart) && ----
137 // X in [-latchStart, guardLimit - 1 - guardStart) => ----
138 // X in [-guardStart - 1, guardLimit - guardStart - 1) ----
139 // == true ----
140 // ----
141 // So the widened condition is: ----
142 // guardStart u< guardLimit && ----
143 // latchStart + guardLimit - 1 - guardStart u>= latchLimit ----
144 // Similarly for ule condition the widened condition is: ----
145 // guardStart u< guardLimit && ----
146 // latchStart + guardLimit - 1 - guardStart u> latchLimit ----
147 // For slt condition the widened condition is: ----
148 // guardStart u< guardLimit && ----
149 // latchStart + guardLimit - 1 - guardStart s>= latchLimit ----
150 // For sle condition the widened condition is: ----
151 // guardStart u< guardLimit && ----
152 // latchStart + guardLimit - 1 - guardStart s> latchLimit ----
153 // ----
154 // When S = -1 (i.e. reverse iterating loop), the transformation is supported ----
155 // when: ----
156 // * The loop has a single latch with the condition of the form: ----
157 // B(X) = X latchLimit, where is u>, u>=, s>, or s>=. ----
158 // * The guard condition is of the form ----
159 // G(X) = X - 1 u< guardLimit ----
160 // ----
161 // For the ugt latch comparison case M is: ----
162 // forall X. X-1 u< guardLimit and X u> latchLimit => X-2 u< guardLimit ----
163 // ----
164 // The only way the antecedent can be true and the consequent can be false is if ----
165 // X == 1. ----
166 // If X == 1 then the second half of the antecedent is ----
167 // 1 u> latchLimit, and its negation is latchLimit u>= 1. ----
168 // ----
169 // So the widened condition is: ----
170 // guardStart u< guardLimit && latchLimit u>= 1. ----
171 // Similarly for sgt condition the widened condition is: ----
172 // guardStart u< guardLimit && latchLimit s>= 1. ----
173 // For uge condition the widened condition is: ----
174 // guardStart u< guardLimit && latchLimit u> 1. ----
175 // For sge condition the widened condition is: ----
176 // guardStart u< guardLimit && latchLimit s> 1. ----
177 //===----------------------------------------------------------------------===// ----

223 // This is the scale factor for the latch probability. We use this during ----
224 // profitability analysis to find other exiting blocks that have a much higher ----
225 // probability of exiting the loop instead of loop exiting via latch. ----
226 // This value should be greater than 1 for a sane profitability check. ----
227 static cl::opt LatchExitProbabilityScale( ----
228 "loop-predication-latch-probability-scale", cl::Hidden, cl::init(2.0), ----
229 cl::desc("scale factor for the latch probability. Value should be greater " ----
230 "than 1. Lower values are ignored")); ----

236 cl::init(true)); ----

245 namespace { ----
246 /// Represents an induction variable check: ----
247 /// icmp Pred, , ----
248 struct LoopICmp { ----
249 ICmpInst::Predicate Pred; ----
250 const SCEVAddRecExpr *IV; ----
251 const SCEV *Limit; ----
252 LoopICmp(ICmpInst::Predicate Pred, const SCEVAddRecExpr *IV, 0
253 const SCEV *Limit) ----
254 : Pred(Pred), IV(IV), Limit(Limit) {} 0
255 LoopICmp() = default; ----
256 void dump() { 0
257 dbgs() << "LoopICmp Pred = " << Pred << ", IV = " << *IV 0
258 << ", Limit = " << *Limit << "\n"; 0
259 } 0
260 }; ----
261 ----
262 class LoopPredication { ----
263 AliasAnalysis *AA; ----
264 DominatorTree *DT; ----
265 ScalarEvolution *SE; ----
266 LoopInfo *LI; ----
267 MemorySSAUpdater *MSSAU; ----
268 ----
269 Loop *L; ----
270 const DataLayout *DL; ----
271 BasicBlock *Preheader; ----
272 LoopICmp LatchCheck; ----
273 ----
274 bool isSupportedStep(const SCEV* Step); ----
275 std::optional parseLoopICmp(ICmpInst *ICI); ----
276 std::optional parseLoopLatchICmp(); ----
277 ----
278 /// Return an insertion point suitable for inserting a safe to speculate ----
279 /// instruction whose only user will be 'User' which has operands 'Ops'. A ----
280 /// trivial result would be the at the User itself, but we try to return a ----
281 /// loop invariant location if possible. ----
282 Instruction *findInsertPt(Instruction *User, ArrayRef Ops); ----
283 /// Same as above, *except* that this uses the SCEV definition of invariant ----
284 /// which is that an expression *can be made* invariant via SCEVExpander. ----
285 /// Thus, this version is only suitable for finding an insert point to be be ----
286 /// passed to SCEVExpander! ----
287 Instruction *findInsertPt(const SCEVExpander &Expander, Instruction *User, ----
288 ArrayRef Ops); ----
289 ----
290 /// Return true if the value is known to produce a single fixed value across ----
291 /// all iterations on which it executes. Note that this does not imply ----
292 /// speculation safety. That must be established separately. ----
293 bool isLoopInvariantValue(const SCEV* S); ----
294 ----
295 Value *expandCheck(SCEVExpander &Expander, Instruction *Guard, ----
296 ICmpInst::Predicate Pred, const SCEV *LHS, ----
297 const SCEV *RHS); ----
298 ----
299 std::optional widenICmpRangeCheck(ICmpInst *ICI, ----
300 SCEVExpander &Expander, ----
301 Instruction *Guard); ----
302 std::optional ----
303 widenICmpRangeCheckIncrementingLoop(LoopICmp LatchCheck, LoopICmp RangeCheck, ----
304 SCEVExpander &Expander, ----
305 Instruction *Guard); ----
306 std::optional ----
307 widenICmpRangeCheckDecrementingLoop(LoopICmp LatchCheck, LoopICmp RangeCheck, ----
308 SCEVExpander &Expander, ----
309 Instruction *Guard); ----
310 unsigned collectChecks(SmallVectorImpl &Checks, Value *Condition, ----
311 SCEVExpander &Expander, Instruction *Guard); ----
312 bool widenGuardConditions(IntrinsicInst *II, SCEVExpander &Expander); ----
313 bool widenWidenableBranchGuardConditions(BranchInst *Guard, SCEVExpander &Expander); ----
314 // If the loop always exits through another block in the loop, we should not ----
315 // predicate based on the latch check. For example, the latch check can be a ----
316 // very coarse grained check and there can be more fine grained exit checks ----
317 // within the loop. ----
318 bool isLoopProfitableToPredicate(); ----
319 ----
320 bool predicateLoopExits(Loop *L, SCEVExpander &Rewriter); ----
321 ----
322 public: ----
323 LoopPredication(AliasAnalysis *AA, DominatorTree *DT, ScalarEvolution *SE, 0
324 LoopInfo *LI, MemorySSAUpdater *MSSAU) ----
325 : AA(AA), DT(DT), SE(SE), LI(LI), MSSAU(MSSAU){}; 0
326 bool runOnLoop(Loop *L); ----
327 }; ----

329 class LoopPredicationLegacyPass : public LoopPass { ----
330 public: ----
331 static char ID; ----
332 LoopPredicationLegacyPass() : LoopPass(ID) { 0
333 initializeLoopPredicationLegacyPassPass(*PassRegistry::getPassRegistry()); 0
334 } 0
335 ----
336 void getAnalysisUsage(AnalysisUsage &AU) const override { 0
337 AU.addRequired(); 0
338 getLoopAnalysisUsage(AU); 0
339 AU.addPreserved(); 0
340 } 0
341 ----
342 bool runOnLoop(Loop *L, LPPassManager &LPM) override { 0
343 if (skipLoop(L)) 0
344 return false; 0
345 auto *SE = &getAnalysis().getSE(); 0
346 auto *LI = &getAnalysis().getLoopInfo(); 0
347 auto *DT = &getAnalysis().getDomTree(); 0
348 auto *MSSAWP = getAnalysisIfAvailable(); 0
349 std::unique_ptr MSSAU; 0
350 if (MSSAWP) 0
351 MSSAU = std::make_unique(&MSSAWP->getMSSA()); 0
352 auto *AA = &getAnalysis().getAAResults(); 0
353 LoopPredication LP(AA, DT, SE, LI, MSSAU ? MSSAU.get() : nullptr); 0
354 return LP.runOnLoop(L); 0
355 } 0
356 }; ----
357 ----
358 char LoopPredicationLegacyPass::ID = 0; ----
359 } // end namespace ----

361 INITIALIZE_PASS_BEGIN(LoopPredicationLegacyPass, "loop-predication", 2 ../DebugInfoTest/example_mips_dbg.ll ../DebugInfoTest/example_mips.ll
362 "Loop predication", false, false) ----
363 INITIALIZE_PASS_DEPENDENCY(BranchProbabilityInfoWrapperPass) 2 ../DebugInfoTest/example_mips_dbg.ll ../DebugInfoTest/example_mips.ll
364 INITIALIZE_PASS_DEPENDENCY(LoopPass) 2 ../DebugInfoTest/example_mips_dbg.ll ../DebugInfoTest/example_mips.ll
365 INITIALIZE_PASS_END(LoopPredicationLegacyPass, "loop-predication", 4 ../DebugInfoTest/example_mips_dbg.ll ../DebugInfoTest/example_mips.ll
366 "Loop predication", false, false) ----
367 ----
368 Pass *llvm::createLoopPredicationPass() { 0
369 return new LoopPredicationLegacyPass(); 0
370 } ----
371 ----
372 PreservedAnalyses LoopPredicationPass::run(Loop &L, LoopAnalysisManager &AM, 0
373 LoopStandardAnalysisResults &AR, ----
374 LPMUpdater &U) { ----
375 std::unique_ptr MSSAU; 0
376 if (AR.MSSA) 0
377 MSSAU = std::make_unique(AR.MSSA); 0
378 LoopPredication LP(&AR.AA, &AR.DT, &AR.SE, &AR.LI, 0
379 MSSAU ? MSSAU.get() : nullptr); 0
380 if (!LP.runOnLoop(&L)) 0
381 return PreservedAnalyses::all(); 0
382 ----
383 auto PA = getLoopPassPreservedAnalyses(); 0
384 if (AR.MSSA) 0
385 PA.preserve(); 0
386 return PA; 0
387 } 0
388 ----
389 std::optional LoopPredication::parseLoopICmp(ICmpInst *ICI) { 0
390 auto Pred = ICI->getPredicate(); 0
391 auto *LHS = ICI->getOperand(0); 0
392 auto *RHS = ICI->getOperand(1); 0
393 ----
394 const SCEV *LHSS = SE->getSCEV(LHS); 0
395 if (isa(LHSS)) 0
396 return std::nullopt; 0
397 const SCEV *RHSS = SE->getSCEV(RHS); 0
398 if (isa(RHSS)) 0
399 return std::nullopt; 0
400 ----
401 // Canonicalize RHS to be loop invariant bound, LHS - a loop computable IV ----
402 if (SE->isLoopInvariant(LHSS, L)) { 0
403 std::swap(LHS, RHS); 0
404 std::swap(LHSS, RHSS); 0
405 Pred = ICmpInst::getSwappedPredicate(Pred); 0
406 } ----
407 ----
408 const SCEVAddRecExpr *AR = dyn_cast(LHSS); 0
409 if (!AR || AR->getLoop() != L) 0
410 return std::nullopt; 0
411 ----
412 return LoopICmp(Pred, AR, RHSS); 0
413 } ----
414 ----
415 Value *LoopPredication::expandCheck(SCEVExpander &Expander, 0
416 Instruction *Guard, ----
417 ICmpInst::Predicate Pred, const SCEV *LHS, ----
418 const SCEV *RHS) { ----
419 Type *Ty = LHS->getType(); 0
420 assert(Ty == RHS->getType() && "expandCheck operands have different types?"); 0
421 ----
422 if (SE->isLoopInvariant(LHS, L) && SE->isLoopInvariant(RHS, L)) { 0
423 IRBuilder<> Builder(Guard); 0
424 if (SE->isLoopEntryGuardedByCond(L, Pred, LHS, RHS)) 0
425 return Builder.getTrue(); 0
426 if (SE->isLoopEntryGuardedByCond(L, ICmpInst::getInversePredicate(Pred), 0
427 LHS, RHS)) ----
428 return Builder.getFalse(); 0
429 } 0
430 ----
431 Value *LHSV = ----
432 Expander.expandCodeFor(LHS, Ty, findInsertPt(Expander, Guard, {LHS})); 0
433 Value *RHSV = ----
434 Expander.expandCodeFor(RHS, Ty, findInsertPt(Expander, Guard, {RHS})); 0
435 IRBuilder<> Builder(findInsertPt(Guard, {LHSV, RHSV})); 0
436 return Builder.CreateICmp(Pred, LHSV, RHSV); 0
437 } 0
438 ----
439 // Returns true if its safe to truncate the IV to RangeCheckType. ----
440 // When the IV type is wider than the range operand type, we can still do loop ----
441 // predication, by generating SCEVs for the range and latch that are of the ----
442 // same type. We achieve this by generating a SCEV truncate expression for the ----
443 // latch IV. This is done iff truncation of the IV is a safe operation, ----
444 // without loss of information. ----
445 // Another way to achieve this is by generating a wider type SCEV for the ----
446 // range check operand, however, this needs a more involved check that ----
447 // operands do not overflow. This can lead to loss of information when the ----
448 // range operand is of the form: add i32 %offset, %iv. We need to prove that ----
449 // sext(x + y) is same as sext(x) + sext(y). ----
450 // This function returns true if we can safely represent the IV type in ----
451 // the RangeCheckType without loss of information. ----
452 static bool isSafeToTruncateWideIVType(const DataLayout &DL, 0
453 ScalarEvolution &SE, ----
454 const LoopICmp LatchCheck, ----
455 Type *RangeCheckType) { ----
456 if (!EnableIVTruncation) 0
457 return false; 0
458 assert(DL.getTypeSizeInBits(LatchCheck.IV->getType()).getFixedValue() > 0
459 DL.getTypeSizeInBits(RangeCheckType).getFixedValue() && ----
460 "Expected latch check IV type to be larger than range check operand " ----
461 "type!"); ----
462 // The start and end values of the IV should be known. This is to guarantee ----
463 // that truncating the wide type will not lose information. ----
464 auto *Limit = dyn_cast(LatchCheck.Limit); 0
465 auto *Start = dyn_cast(LatchCheck.IV->getStart()); 0
466 if (!Limit || !Start) 0
467 return false; 0
468 // This check makes sure that the IV does not change sign during loop ----
469 // iterations. Consider latchType = i64, LatchStart = 5, Pred = ICMP_SGE, ----
470 // LatchEnd = 2, rangeCheckType = i32. If it's not a monotonic predicate, the ----
471 // IV wraps around, and the truncation of the IV would lose the range of ----
472 // iterations between 2^32 and 2^64. ----
473 if (!SE.getMonotonicPredicateType(LatchCheck.IV, LatchCheck.Pred)) 0
474 return false; 0
475 // The active bits should be less than the bits in the RangeCheckType. This ----
476 // guarantees that truncating the latch check to RangeCheckType is a safe ----
477 // operation. ----
478 auto RangeCheckTypeBitSize = ----
479 DL.getTypeSizeInBits(RangeCheckType).getFixedValue(); 0
480 return Start->getAPInt().getActiveBits() < RangeCheckTypeBitSize && 0
481 Limit->getAPInt().getActiveBits() < RangeCheckTypeBitSize; 0
482 } ----
483 ----
484 ----
485 // Return an LoopICmp describing a latch check equivlent to LatchCheck but with ----
486 // the requested type if safe to do so. May involve the use of a new IV. ----
487 static std::optional generateLoopLatchCheck(const DataLayout &DL, 0
488 ScalarEvolution &SE, ----
489 const LoopICmp LatchCheck, ----
490 Type *RangeCheckType) { ----
491 ----
492 auto *LatchType = LatchCheck.IV->getType(); 0
493 if (RangeCheckType == LatchType) 0
494 return LatchCheck; 0
495 // For now, bail out if latch type is narrower than range type. ----
496 if (DL.getTypeSizeInBits(LatchType).getFixedValue() < 0
497 DL.getTypeSizeInBits(RangeCheckType).getFixedValue()) 0
498 return std::nullopt; 0
499 if (!isSafeToTruncateWideIVType(DL, SE, LatchCheck, RangeCheckType)) 0
500 return std::nullopt; 0
501 // We can now safely identify the truncated version of the IV and limit for ----
502 // RangeCheckType. ----
503 LoopICmp NewLatchCheck; ----
504 NewLatchCheck.Pred = LatchCheck.Pred; 0
505 NewLatchCheck.IV = dyn_cast( 0
506 SE.getTruncateExpr(LatchCheck.IV, RangeCheckType)); 0
507 if (!NewLatchCheck.IV) 0
508 return std::nullopt; 0
509 NewLatchCheck.Limit = SE.getTruncateExpr(LatchCheck.Limit, RangeCheckType); 0
510 LLVM_DEBUG(dbgs() << "IV of type: " << *LatchType 0
511 << "can be represented as range check type:" ----
512 << *RangeCheckType << "\n"); ----
513 LLVM_DEBUG(dbgs() << "LatchCheck.IV: " << *NewLatchCheck.IV << "\n"); 0
514 LLVM_DEBUG(dbgs() << "LatchCheck.Limit: " << *NewLatchCheck.Limit << "\n"); 0
515 return NewLatchCheck; 0
516 } ----
517 ----
518 bool LoopPredication::isSupportedStep(const SCEV* Step) { 0
519 return Step->isOne() || (Step->isAllOnesValue() && EnableCountDownLoop); 0
520 } ----
521 ----
522 Instruction *LoopPredication::findInsertPt(Instruction *Use, 0
523 ArrayRef Ops) { ----
524 for (Value *Op : Ops) 0
525 if (!L->isLoopInvariant(Op)) 0
526 return Use; 0
527 return Preheader->getTerminator(); 0
528 } ----
529 ----
530 Instruction *LoopPredication::findInsertPt(const SCEVExpander &Expander, 0
531 Instruction *Use, ----
532 ArrayRef Ops) { ----
533 // Subtlety: SCEV considers things to be invariant if the value produced is ----
534 // the same across iterations. This is not the same as being able to ----
535 // evaluate outside the loop, which is what we actually need here. ----
536 for (const SCEV *Op : Ops) 0
537 if (!SE->isLoopInvariant(Op, L) || 0
538 !Expander.isSafeToExpandAt(Op, Preheader->getTerminator())) 0
539 return Use; 0
540 return Preheader->getTerminator(); 0
541 } ----
542 ----
543 bool LoopPredication::isLoopInvariantValue(const SCEV* S) { 0
544 // Handling expressions which produce invariant results, but *haven't* yet ----
545 // been removed from the loop serves two important purposes. ----
546 // 1) Most importantly, it resolves a pass ordering cycle which would ----
547 // otherwise need us to iteration licm, loop-predication, and either ----
548 // loop-unswitch or loop-peeling to make progress on examples with lots of ----
549 // predicable range checks in a row. (Since, in the general case, we can't ----
550 // hoist the length checks until the dominating checks have been discharged ----
551 // as we can't prove doing so is safe.) ----
552 // 2) As a nice side effect, this exposes the value of peeling or unswitching ----
553 // much more obviously in the IR. Otherwise, the cost modeling for other ----
554 // transforms would end up needing to duplicate all of this logic to model a ----
555 // check which becomes predictable based on a modeled peel or unswitch. ----
556 // ----
557 // The cost of doing so in the worst case is an extra fill from the stack in ----
558 // the loop to materialize the loop invariant test value instead of checking ----
559 // against the original IV which is presumable in a register inside the loop. ----
560 // Such cases are presumably rare, and hint at missing oppurtunities for ----
561 // other passes. ----
562 ----
563 if (SE->isLoopInvariant(S, L)) 0
564 // Note: This the SCEV variant, so the original Value* may be within the ----
565 // loop even though SCEV has proven it is loop invariant. ----
566 return true; 0
567 ----
568 // Handle a particular important case which SCEV doesn't yet know about which ----
569 // shows up in range checks on arrays with immutable lengths. ----
570 // TODO: This should be sunk inside SCEV. ----
571 if (const SCEVUnknown *U = dyn_cast(S)) 0
572 if (const auto *LI = dyn_cast(U->getValue())) 0
573 if (LI->isUnordered() && L->hasLoopInvariantOperands(LI)) 0
574 if (!isModSet(AA->getModRefInfoMask(LI->getOperand(0))) || 0
575 LI->hasMetadata(LLVMContext::MD_invariant_load)) 0
576 return true; 0
577 return false; 0
578 } ----
579 ----
580 std::optional LoopPredication::widenICmpRangeCheckIncrementingLoop( 0
581 LoopICmp LatchCheck, LoopICmp RangeCheck, SCEVExpander &Expander, ----
582 Instruction *Guard) { ----
583 auto *Ty = RangeCheck.IV->getType(); 0
584 // Generate the widened condition for the forward loop: ----
585 // guardStart u< guardLimit && ----
586 // latchLimit guardLimit - 1 - guardStart + latchStart ----
587 // where depends on the latch condition predicate. See the file ----
588 // header comment for the reasoning. ----
589 // guardLimit - guardStart + latchStart - 1 ----
590 const SCEV *GuardStart = RangeCheck.IV->getStart(); 0
591 const SCEV *GuardLimit = RangeCheck.Limit; 0
592 const SCEV *LatchStart = LatchCheck.IV->getStart(); 0
593 const SCEV *LatchLimit = LatchCheck.Limit; 0
594 // Subtlety: We need all the values to be *invariant* across all iterations, ----
595 // but we only need to check expansion safety for those which *aren't* ----
596 // already guaranteed to dominate the guard. ----
597 if (!isLoopInvariantValue(GuardStart) || 0
598 !isLoopInvariantValue(GuardLimit) || 0
599 !isLoopInvariantValue(LatchStart) || 0
600 !isLoopInvariantValue(LatchLimit)) { 0
601 LLVM_DEBUG(dbgs() << "Can't expand limit check!\n"); 0
602 return std::nullopt; 0
603 } ----
604 if (!Expander.isSafeToExpandAt(LatchStart, Guard) || 0
605 !Expander.isSafeToExpandAt(LatchLimit, Guard)) { 0
606 LLVM_DEBUG(dbgs() << "Can't expand limit check!\n"); 0
607 return std::nullopt; 0
608 } ----
609 ----
610 // guardLimit - guardStart + latchStart - 1 ----
611 const SCEV *RHS = ----
612 SE->getAddExpr(SE->getMinusSCEV(GuardLimit, GuardStart), 0
613 SE->getMinusSCEV(LatchStart, SE->getOne(Ty))); 0
614 auto LimitCheckPred = ----
615 ICmpInst::getFlippedStrictnessPredicate(LatchCheck.Pred); 0
616 ----
617 LLVM_DEBUG(dbgs() << "LHS: " << *LatchLimit << "\n"); 0
618 LLVM_DEBUG(dbgs() << "RHS: " << *RHS << "\n"); 0
619 LLVM_DEBUG(dbgs() << "Pred: " << LimitCheckPred << "\n"); 0
620 ----
621 auto *LimitCheck = ----
622 expandCheck(Expander, Guard, LimitCheckPred, LatchLimit, RHS); 0
623 auto *FirstIterationCheck = expandCheck(Expander, Guard, RangeCheck.Pred, 0
624 GuardStart, GuardLimit); ----
625 IRBuilder<> Builder(findInsertPt(Guard, {FirstIterationCheck, LimitCheck})); 0
626 return Builder.CreateFreeze( 0
627 Builder.CreateAnd(FirstIterationCheck, LimitCheck)); 0
628 } 0
629 ----
630 std::optional LoopPredication::widenICmpRangeCheckDecrementingLoop( 0
631 LoopICmp LatchCheck, LoopICmp RangeCheck, SCEVExpander &Expander, ----
632 Instruction *Guard) { ----
633 auto *Ty = RangeCheck.IV->getType(); 0
634 const SCEV *GuardStart = RangeCheck.IV->getStart(); 0
635 const SCEV *GuardLimit = RangeCheck.Limit; 0
636 const SCEV *LatchStart = LatchCheck.IV->getStart(); 0
637 const SCEV *LatchLimit = LatchCheck.Limit; 0
638 // Subtlety: We need all the values to be *invariant* across all iterations, ----
639 // but we only need to check expansion safety for those which *aren't* ----
640 // already guaranteed to dominate the guard. ----
641 if (!isLoopInvariantValue(GuardStart) || 0
642 !isLoopInvariantValue(GuardLimit) || 0
643 !isLoopInvariantValue(LatchStart) || 0
644 !isLoopInvariantValue(LatchLimit)) { 0
645 LLVM_DEBUG(dbgs() << "Can't expand limit check!\n"); 0
646 return std::nullopt; 0
647 } ----
648 if (!Expander.isSafeToExpandAt(LatchStart, Guard) || 0
649 !Expander.isSafeToExpandAt(LatchLimit, Guard)) { 0
650 LLVM_DEBUG(dbgs() << "Can't expand limit check!\n"); 0
651 return std::nullopt; 0
652 } ----
653 // The decrement of the latch check IV should be the same as the ----
654 // rangeCheckIV. ----
655 auto *PostDecLatchCheckIV = LatchCheck.IV->getPostIncExpr(*SE); 0
656 if (RangeCheck.IV != PostDecLatchCheckIV) { 0
657 LLVM_DEBUG(dbgs() << "Not the same. PostDecLatchCheckIV: " 0
658 << *PostDecLatchCheckIV ----
659 << " and RangeCheckIV: " << *RangeCheck.IV << "\n"); ----
660 return std::nullopt; 0
661 } ----
662 ----
663 // Generate the widened condition for CountDownLoop: ----
664 // guardStart u< guardLimit && ----
665 // latchLimit 1. ----
666 // See the header comment for reasoning of the checks. ----
667 auto LimitCheckPred = ----
668 ICmpInst::getFlippedStrictnessPredicate(LatchCheck.Pred); 0
669 auto *FirstIterationCheck = expandCheck(Expander, Guard, 0
670 ICmpInst::ICMP_ULT, ----
671 GuardStart, GuardLimit); ----
672 auto *LimitCheck = expandCheck(Expander, Guard, LimitCheckPred, LatchLimit, 0
673 SE->getOne(Ty)); 0
674 IRBuilder<> Builder(findInsertPt(Guard, {FirstIterationCheck, LimitCheck})); 0
675 return Builder.CreateFreeze( 0
676 Builder.CreateAnd(FirstIterationCheck, LimitCheck)); 0
677 } 0
678 ----
679 static void normalizePredicate(ScalarEvolution *SE, Loop *L, 0
680 LoopICmp& RC) { ----
681 // LFTR canonicalizes checks to the ICMP_NE/EQ form; normalize back to the ----
682 // ULT/UGE form for ease of handling by our caller. ----
683 if (ICmpInst::isEquality(RC.Pred) && 0
684 RC.IV->getStepRecurrence(*SE)->isOne() && 0
685 SE->isKnownPredicate(ICmpInst::ICMP_ULE, RC.IV->getStart(), RC.Limit)) 0
686 RC.Pred = RC.Pred == ICmpInst::ICMP_NE ? 0
687 ICmpInst::ICMP_ULT : ICmpInst::ICMP_UGE; ----
688 } 0
689 ----
690 /// If ICI can be widened to a loop invariant condition emits the loop ----
691 /// invariant condition in the loop preheader and return it, otherwise ----
692 /// returns std::nullopt. ----
693 std::optional ----
694 LoopPredication::widenICmpRangeCheck(ICmpInst *ICI, SCEVExpander &Expander, 0
695 Instruction *Guard) { ----
696 LLVM_DEBUG(dbgs() << "Analyzing ICmpInst condition:\n"); 0
697 LLVM_DEBUG(ICI->dump()); 0
698 ----
699 // parseLoopStructure guarantees that the latch condition is: ----
700 // ++i latchLimit, where is u<, u<=, s<, or s<=. ----
701 // We are looking for the range checks of the form: ----
702 // i u< guardLimit ----
703 auto RangeCheck = parseLoopICmp(ICI); 0
704 if (!RangeCheck) { 0
705 LLVM_DEBUG(dbgs() << "Failed to parse the loop latch condition!\n"); 0
706 return std::nullopt; 0
707 } ----
708 LLVM_DEBUG(dbgs() << "Guard check:\n"); 0
709 LLVM_DEBUG(RangeCheck->dump()); 0
710 if (RangeCheck->Pred != ICmpInst::ICMP_ULT) { 0
711 LLVM_DEBUG(dbgs() << "Unsupported range check predicate(" 0
712 << RangeCheck->Pred << ")!\n"); ----
713 return std::nullopt; 0
714 } ----
715 auto *RangeCheckIV = RangeCheck->IV; 0
716 if (!RangeCheckIV->isAffine()) { 0
717 LLVM_DEBUG(dbgs() << "Range check IV is not affine!\n"); 0
718 return std::nullopt; 0
719 } ----
720 auto *Step = RangeCheckIV->getStepRecurrence(*SE); 0
721 // We cannot just compare with latch IV step because the latch and range IVs ----
722 // may have different types. ----
723 if (!isSupportedStep(Step)) { 0
724 LLVM_DEBUG(dbgs() << "Range check and latch have IVs different steps!\n"); 0
725 return std::nullopt; 0
726 } ----
727 auto *Ty = RangeCheckIV->getType(); 0
728 auto CurrLatchCheckOpt = generateLoopLatchCheck(*DL, *SE, LatchCheck, Ty); 0
729 if (!CurrLatchCheckOpt) { 0
730 LLVM_DEBUG(dbgs() << "Failed to generate a loop latch check " 0
731 "corresponding to range type: " ----
732 << *Ty << "\n"); ----
733 return std::nullopt; 0
734 } ----
735 ----
736 LoopICmp CurrLatchCheck = *CurrLatchCheckOpt; 0
737 // At this point, the range and latch step should have the same type, but need ----
738 // not have the same value (we support both 1 and -1 steps). ----
739 assert(Step->getType() == 0
740 CurrLatchCheck.IV->getStepRecurrence(*SE)->getType() && ----
741 "Range and latch steps should be of same type!"); ----
742 if (Step != CurrLatchCheck.IV->getStepRecurrence(*SE)) { 0
743 LLVM_DEBUG(dbgs() << "Range and latch have different step values!\n"); 0
744 return std::nullopt; 0
745 } ----
746 ----
747 if (Step->isOne()) 0
748 return widenICmpRangeCheckIncrementingLoop(CurrLatchCheck, *RangeCheck, 0
749 Expander, Guard); 0
750 else { ----
751 assert(Step->isAllOnesValue() && "Step should be -1!"); 0
752 return widenICmpRangeCheckDecrementingLoop(CurrLatchCheck, *RangeCheck, 0
753 Expander, Guard); 0
754 } ----
755 } ----
756 ----
757 unsigned LoopPredication::collectChecks(SmallVectorImpl &Checks, 0
758 Value *Condition, ----
759 SCEVExpander &Expander, ----
760 Instruction *Guard) { ----
761 unsigned NumWidened = 0; 0
762 // The guard condition is expected to be in form of: ----
763 // cond1 && cond2 && cond3 ... ----
764 // Iterate over subconditions looking for icmp conditions which can be ----
765 // widened across loop iterations. Widening these conditions remember the ----
766 // resulting list of subconditions in Checks vector. ----
767 SmallVector Worklist(1, Condition); 0
768 SmallPtrSet Visited; 0
769 Visited.insert(Condition); 0
770 Value *WideableCond = nullptr; 0
771 do { ----
772 Value *Condition = Worklist.pop_back_val(); 0
773 Value *LHS, *RHS; ----
774 using namespace llvm::PatternMatch; ----
775 if (match(Condition, m_And(m_Value(LHS), m_Value(RHS)))) { 0
776 if (Visited.insert(LHS).second) 0
777 Worklist.push_back(LHS); 0
778 if (Visited.insert(RHS).second) 0
779 Worklist.push_back(RHS); 0
780 continue; 0
781 } ----
782 ----
783 if (match(Condition, 0
784 m_Intrinsic())) { 0
785 // Pick any, we don't care which ----
786 WideableCond = Condition; 0
787 continue; 0
788 } ----
789 ----
790 if (ICmpInst *ICI = dyn_cast(Condition)) { 0
791 if (auto NewRangeCheck = widenICmpRangeCheck(ICI, Expander, 0
792 Guard)) { 0
793 Checks.push_back(*NewRangeCheck); 0
794 NumWidened++; 0
795 continue; 0
796 } ----
797 } ----
798 ----
799 // Save the condition as is if we can't widen it ----
800 Checks.push_back(Condition); 0
801 } while (!Worklist.empty()); 0
802 // At the moment, our matching logic for wideable conditions implicitly ----
803 // assumes we preserve the form: (br (and Cond, WC())). FIXME ----
804 // Note that if there were multiple calls to wideable condition in the ----
805 // traversal, we only need to keep one, and which one is arbitrary. ----
806 if (WideableCond) 0
807 Checks.push_back(WideableCond); 0
808 return NumWidened; 0
809 } 0
810 ----
811 bool LoopPredication::widenGuardConditions(IntrinsicInst *Guard, 0
812 SCEVExpander &Expander) { ----
813 LLVM_DEBUG(dbgs() << "Processing guard:\n"); 0
814 LLVM_DEBUG(Guard->dump()); 0
815 ----
816 TotalConsidered++; 0
817 SmallVector Checks; 0
818 unsigned NumWidened = collectChecks(Checks, Guard->getOperand(0), Expander, 0
819 Guard); ----
820 if (NumWidened == 0) 0
821 return false; 0
822 ----
823 TotalWidened += NumWidened; 0
824 ----
825 // Emit the new guard condition ----
826 IRBuilder<> Builder(findInsertPt(Guard, Checks)); 0
827 Value *AllChecks = Builder.CreateAnd(Checks); 0
828 auto *OldCond = Guard->getOperand(0); 0
829 Guard->setOperand(0, AllChecks); 0
830 if (InsertAssumesOfPredicatedGuardsConditions) { 0
831 Builder.SetInsertPoint(&*++BasicBlock::iterator(Guard)); 0
832 Builder.CreateAssumption(OldCond); 0
833 } ----
834 RecursivelyDeleteTriviallyDeadInstructions(OldCond, nullptr /* TLI */, MSSAU); 0
835 ----
836 LLVM_DEBUG(dbgs() << "Widened checks = " << NumWidened << "\n"); 0
837 return true; 0
838 } 0
839 ----
840 bool LoopPredication::widenWidenableBranchGuardConditions( 0
841 BranchInst *BI, SCEVExpander &Expander) { ----
842 assert(isGuardAsWidenableBranch(BI) && "Must be!"); 0
843 LLVM_DEBUG(dbgs() << "Processing guard:\n"); 0
844 LLVM_DEBUG(BI->dump()); 0
845 ----
846 Value *Cond, *WC; ----
847 BasicBlock *IfTrueBB, *IfFalseBB; ----
848 bool Parsed = parseWidenableBranch(BI, Cond, WC, IfTrueBB, IfFalseBB); 0
849 assert(Parsed && "Must be able to parse widenable branch"); 0
850 (void)Parsed; ----
851 ----
852 TotalConsidered++; 0
853 SmallVector Checks; 0
854 unsigned NumWidened = collectChecks(Checks, BI->getCondition(), 0
855 Expander, BI); ----
856 if (NumWidened == 0) 0
857 return false; 0
858 ----
859 TotalWidened += NumWidened; 0
860 ----
861 // Emit the new guard condition ----
862 IRBuilder<> Builder(findInsertPt(BI, Checks)); 0
863 Value *AllChecks = Builder.CreateAnd(Checks); 0
864 auto *OldCond = BI->getCondition(); 0
865 BI->setCondition(AllChecks); 0
866 if (InsertAssumesOfPredicatedGuardsConditions) { 0
867 Builder.SetInsertPoint(IfTrueBB, IfTrueBB->getFirstInsertionPt()); 0
868 // If this block has other predecessors, we might not be able to use Cond. ----
869 // In this case, create a Phi where every other input is `true` and input ----
870 // from guard block is Cond. ----
871 Value *AssumeCond = Cond; 0
872 if (!IfTrueBB->getUniquePredecessor()) { 0
873 auto *GuardBB = BI->getParent(); 0
874 auto *PN = Builder.CreatePHI(Cond->getType(), pred_size(IfTrueBB), 0
875 "assume.cond"); ----
876 for (auto *Pred : predecessors(IfTrueBB)) 0
877 PN->addIncoming(Pred == GuardBB ? Cond : Builder.getTrue(), Pred); 0
878 AssumeCond = PN; 0
879 } ----
880 Builder.CreateAssumption(AssumeCond); 0
881 } ----
882 RecursivelyDeleteTriviallyDeadInstructions(OldCond, nullptr /* TLI */, MSSAU); 0
883 assert(isGuardAsWidenableBranch(BI) && 0
884 "Stopped being a guard after transform?"); ----
885 ----
886 LLVM_DEBUG(dbgs() << "Widened checks = " << NumWidened << "\n"); 0
887 return true; 0
888 } 0
889 ----
890 std::optional LoopPredication::parseLoopLatchICmp() { 0
891 using namespace PatternMatch; ----
892 ----
893 BasicBlock *LoopLatch = L->getLoopLatch(); 0
894 if (!LoopLatch) { 0
895 LLVM_DEBUG(dbgs() << "The loop doesn't have a single latch!\n"); 0
896 return std::nullopt; 0
897 } ----
898 ----
899 auto *BI = dyn_cast(LoopLatch->getTerminator()); 0
900 if (!BI || !BI->isConditional()) { 0
901 LLVM_DEBUG(dbgs() << "Failed to match the latch terminator!\n"); 0
902 return std::nullopt; 0
903 } ----
904 BasicBlock *TrueDest = BI->getSuccessor(0); 0
905 assert( 0
906 (TrueDest == L->getHeader() || BI->getSuccessor(1) == L->getHeader()) && ----
907 "One of the latch's destinations must be the header"); ----
908 ----
909 auto *ICI = dyn_cast(BI->getCondition()); 0
910 if (!ICI) { 0
911 LLVM_DEBUG(dbgs() << "Failed to match the latch condition!\n"); 0
912 return std::nullopt; 0
913 } ----
914 auto Result = parseLoopICmp(ICI); 0
915 if (!Result) { 0
916 LLVM_DEBUG(dbgs() << "Failed to parse the loop latch condition!\n"); 0
917 return std::nullopt; 0
918 } ----
919 ----
920 if (TrueDest != L->getHeader()) 0
921 Result->Pred = ICmpInst::getInversePredicate(Result->Pred); 0
922 ----
923 // Check affine first, so if it's not we don't try to compute the step ----
924 // recurrence. ----
925 if (!Result->IV->isAffine()) { 0
926 LLVM_DEBUG(dbgs() << "The induction variable is not affine!\n"); 0
927 return std::nullopt; 0
928 } ----
929 ----
930 auto *Step = Result->IV->getStepRecurrence(*SE); 0
931 if (!isSupportedStep(Step)) { 0
932 LLVM_DEBUG(dbgs() << "Unsupported loop stride(" << *Step << ")!\n"); 0
933 return std::nullopt; 0
934 } ----
935 ----
936 auto IsUnsupportedPredicate = [](const SCEV *Step, ICmpInst::Predicate Pred) { 0
937 if (Step->isOne()) { 0
938 return Pred != ICmpInst::ICMP_ULT && Pred != ICmpInst::ICMP_SLT && 0
939 Pred != ICmpInst::ICMP_ULE && Pred != ICmpInst::ICMP_SLE; 0
940 } else { ----
941 assert(Step->isAllOnesValue() && "Step should be -1!"); 0
942 return Pred != ICmpInst::ICMP_UGT && Pred != ICmpInst::ICMP_SGT && 0
943 Pred != ICmpInst::ICMP_UGE && Pred != ICmpInst::ICMP_SGE; 0
944 } ----
945 }; ----
946 ----
947 normalizePredicate(SE, L, *Result); 0
948 if (IsUnsupportedPredicate(Step, Result->Pred)) { 0
949 LLVM_DEBUG(dbgs() << "Unsupported loop latch predicate(" << Result->Pred 0
950 << ")!\n"); ----
951 return std::nullopt; 0
952 } ----
953 ----
954 return Result; 0
955 } ----
956 ----
957 bool LoopPredication::isLoopProfitableToPredicate() { 0
958 if (SkipProfitabilityChecks) 0
959 return true; 0
960 ----
961 SmallVector, 8> ExitEdges; 0
962 L->getExitEdges(ExitEdges); 0
963 // If there is only one exiting edge in the loop, it is always profitable to ----
964 // predicate the loop. ----
965 if (ExitEdges.size() == 1) 0
966 return true; 0
967 ----
968 // Calculate the exiting probabilities of all exiting edges from the loop, ----
969 // starting with the LatchExitProbability. ----
970 // Heuristic for profitability: If any of the exiting blocks' probability of ----
971 // exiting the loop is larger than exiting through the latch block, it's not ----
972 // profitable to predicate the loop. ----
973 auto *LatchBlock = L->getLoopLatch(); 0
974 assert(LatchBlock && "Should have a single latch at this point!"); 0
975 auto *LatchTerm = LatchBlock->getTerminator(); 0
976 assert(LatchTerm->getNumSuccessors() == 2 && 0
977 "expected to be an exiting block with 2 succs!"); ----
978 unsigned LatchBrExitIdx = ----
979 LatchTerm->getSuccessor(0) == L->getHeader() ? 1 : 0; 0
980 // We compute branch probabilities without BPI. We do not rely on BPI since ----
981 // Loop predication is usually run in an LPM and BPI is only preserved ----
982 // lossily within loop pass managers, while BPI has an inherent notion of ----
983 // being complete for an entire function. ----
984 ----
985 // If the latch exits into a deoptimize or an unreachable block, do not ----
986 // predicate on that latch check. ----
987 auto *LatchExitBlock = LatchTerm->getSuccessor(LatchBrExitIdx); 0
988 if (isa(LatchTerm) || 0
989 LatchExitBlock->getTerminatingDeoptimizeCall()) 0
990 return false; 0
991 ----
992 // Latch terminator has no valid profile data, so nothing to check ----
993 // profitability on. ----
994 if (!hasValidBranchWeightMD(*LatchTerm)) 0
995 return true; 0
996 ----
997 auto ComputeBranchProbability = ----
998 [&](const BasicBlock *ExitingBlock, 0
999 const BasicBlock *ExitBlock) -> BranchProbability { ----
1000 auto *Term = ExitingBlock->getTerminator(); 0
1001 unsigned NumSucc = Term->getNumSuccessors(); 0
1002 if (MDNode *ProfileData = getValidBranchWeightMDNode(*Term)) { 0
1003 SmallVector Weights; 0
1004 extractBranchWeights(ProfileData, Weights); 0
1005 uint64_t Numerator = 0, Denominator = 0; 0
1006 for (auto [i, Weight] : llvm::enumerate(Weights)) { 0
1007 if (Term->getSuccessor(i) == ExitBlock) 0
1008 Numerator += Weight; 0
1009 Denominator += Weight; 0
1010 } ----
1011 return BranchProbability::getBranchProbability(Numerator, Denominator); 0
1012 } else { 0
1013 assert(LatchBlock != ExitingBlock && 0
1014 "Latch term should always have profile data!"); ----
1015 // No profile data, so we choose the weight as 1/num_of_succ(Src) ----
1016 return BranchProbability::getBranchProbability(1, NumSucc); 0
1017 } ----
1018 }; 0
1019 ----
1020 BranchProbability LatchExitProbability = ----
1021 ComputeBranchProbability(LatchBlock, LatchExitBlock); 0
1022 ----
1023 // Protect against degenerate inputs provided by the user. Providing a value ----
1024 // less than one, can invert the definition of profitable loop predication. ----
1025 float ScaleFactor = LatchExitProbabilityScale; 0
1026 if (ScaleFactor < 1) { 0
1027 LLVM_DEBUG( 0
1028 dbgs() ----
1029 << "Ignored user setting for loop-predication-latch-probability-scale: " ----
1030 << LatchExitProbabilityScale << "\n"); ----
1031 LLVM_DEBUG(dbgs() << "The value is set to 1.0\n"); 0
1032 ScaleFactor = 1.0; 0
1033 } ----
1034 const auto LatchProbabilityThreshold = LatchExitProbability * ScaleFactor; 0
1035 ----
1036 for (const auto &ExitEdge : ExitEdges) { 0
1037 BranchProbability ExitingBlockProbability = ----
1038 ComputeBranchProbability(ExitEdge.first, ExitEdge.second); 0
1039 // Some exiting edge has higher probability than the latch exiting edge. ----
1040 // No longer profitable to predicate. ----
1041 if (ExitingBlockProbability > LatchProbabilityThreshold) 0
1042 return false; 0
1043 } ----
1044 ----
1045 // We have concluded that the most probable way to exit from the ----
1046 // loop is through the latch (or there's no profile information and all ----
1047 // exits are equally likely). ----
1048 return true; 0
1049 } 0
1050 ----
1051 /// If we can (cheaply) find a widenable branch which controls entry into the ----
1052 /// loop, return it. ----
1053 static BranchInst *FindWidenableTerminatorAboveLoop(Loop *L, LoopInfo &LI) { 0
1054 // Walk back through any unconditional executed blocks and see if we can find ----
1055 // a widenable condition which seems to control execution of this loop. Note ----
1056 // that we predict that maythrow calls are likely untaken and thus that it's ----
1057 // profitable to widen a branch before a maythrow call with a condition ----
1058 // afterwards even though that may cause the slow path to run in a case where ----
1059 // it wouldn't have otherwise. ----
1060 BasicBlock *BB = L->getLoopPreheader(); 0
1061 if (!BB) 0
1062 return nullptr; 0
1063 do { ----
1064 if (BasicBlock *Pred = BB->getSinglePredecessor()) 0
1065 if (BB == Pred->getSingleSuccessor()) { 0
1066 BB = Pred; 0
1067 continue; 0
1068 } ----
1069 break; 0
1070 } while (true); 0
1071 ----
1072 if (BasicBlock *Pred = BB->getSinglePredecessor()) { 0
1073 auto *Term = Pred->getTerminator(); 0
1074 ----
1075 Value *Cond, *WC; ----
1076 BasicBlock *IfTrueBB, *IfFalseBB; ----
1077 if (parseWidenableBranch(Term, Cond, WC, IfTrueBB, IfFalseBB) && 0
1078 IfTrueBB == BB) 0
1079 return cast(Term); 0
1080 } ----
1081 return nullptr; 0
1082 } ----
1083 ----
1084 /// Return the minimum of all analyzeable exit counts. This is an upper bound ----
1085 /// on the actual exit count. If there are not at least two analyzeable exits, ----
1086 /// returns SCEVCouldNotCompute. ----
1087 static const SCEV *getMinAnalyzeableBackedgeTakenCount(ScalarEvolution &SE, 0
1088 DominatorTree &DT, ----
1089 Loop *L) { ----
1090 SmallVector ExitingBlocks; 0
1091 L->getExitingBlocks(ExitingBlocks); 0
1092 ----
1093 SmallVector ExitCounts; 0
1094 for (BasicBlock *ExitingBB : ExitingBlocks) { 0
1095 const SCEV *ExitCount = SE.getExitCount(L, ExitingBB); 0
1096 if (isa(ExitCount)) 0
1097 continue; 0
1098 assert(DT.dominates(ExitingBB, L->getLoopLatch()) && 0
1099 "We should only have known counts for exiting blocks that " ----
1100 "dominate latch!"); ----
1101 ExitCounts.push_back(ExitCount); 0
1102 } ----
1103 if (ExitCounts.size() < 2) 0
1104 return SE.getCouldNotCompute(); 0
1105 return SE.getUMinFromMismatchedTypes(ExitCounts); 0
1106 } 0
1107 ----
1108 /// This implements an analogous, but entirely distinct transform from the main ----
1109 /// loop predication transform. This one is phrased in terms of using a ----
1110 /// widenable branch *outside* the loop to allow us to simplify loop exits in a ----
1111 /// following loop. This is close in spirit to the IndVarSimplify transform ----
1112 /// of the same name, but is materially different widening loosens legality ----
1113 /// sharply. ----
1114 bool LoopPredication::predicateLoopExits(Loop *L, SCEVExpander &Rewriter) { 0
1115 // The transformation performed here aims to widen a widenable condition ----
1116 // above the loop such that all analyzeable exit leading to deopt are dead. ----
1117 // It assumes that the latch is the dominant exit for profitability and that ----
1118 // exits branching to deoptimizing blocks are rarely taken. It relies on the ----
1119 // semantics of widenable expressions for legality. (i.e. being able to fall ----
1120 // down the widenable path spuriously allows us to ignore exit order, ----
1121 // unanalyzeable exits, side effects, exceptional exits, and other challenges ----
1122 // which restrict the applicability of the non-WC based version of this ----
1123 // transform in IndVarSimplify.) ----
1124 // ----
1125 // NOTE ON POISON/UNDEF - We're hoisting an expression above guards which may ----
1126 // imply flags on the expression being hoisted and inserting new uses (flags ----
1127 // are only correct for current uses). The result is that we may be ----
1128 // inserting a branch on the value which can be either poison or undef. In ----
1129 // this case, the branch can legally go either way; we just need to avoid ----
1130 // introducing UB. This is achieved through the use of the freeze ----
1131 // instruction. ----
1132 ----
1133 SmallVector ExitingBlocks; 0
1134 L->getExitingBlocks(ExitingBlocks); 0
1135 ----
1136 if (ExitingBlocks.empty()) 0
1137 return false; // Nothing to do. 0
1138 ----
1139 auto *Latch = L->getLoopLatch(); 0
1140 if (!Latch) 0
1141 return false; 0
1142 ----
1143 auto *WidenableBR = FindWidenableTerminatorAboveLoop(L, *LI); 0
1144 if (!WidenableBR) 0
1145 return false; 0
1146 ----
1147 const SCEV *LatchEC = SE->getExitCount(L, Latch); 0
1148 if (isa(LatchEC)) 0
1149 return false; // profitability - want hot exit in analyzeable set 0
1150 ----
1151 // At this point, we have found an analyzeable latch, and a widenable ----
1152 // condition above the loop. If we have a widenable exit within the loop ----
1153 // (for which we can't compute exit counts), drop the ability to further ----
1154 // widen so that we gain ability to analyze it's exit count and perform this ----
1155 // transform. TODO: It'd be nice to know for sure the exit became ----
1156 // analyzeable after dropping widenability. ----
1157 bool ChangedLoop = false; 0
1158 ----
1159 for (auto *ExitingBB : ExitingBlocks) { 0
1160 if (LI->getLoopFor(ExitingBB) != L) 0
1161 continue; 0
1162 ----
1163 auto *BI = dyn_cast(ExitingBB->getTerminator()); 0
1164 if (!BI) 0
1165 continue; 0
1166 ----
1167 Use *Cond, *WC; ----
1168 BasicBlock *IfTrueBB, *IfFalseBB; ----
1169 if (parseWidenableBranch(BI, Cond, WC, IfTrueBB, IfFalseBB) && 0
1170 L->contains(IfTrueBB)) { 0
1171 WC->set(ConstantInt::getTrue(IfTrueBB->getContext())); 0
1172 ChangedLoop = true; 0
1173 } ----
1174 } ----
1175 if (ChangedLoop) 0
1176 SE->forgetLoop(L); 0
1177 ----
1178 // The insertion point for the widening should be at the widenably call, not ----
1179 // at the WidenableBR. If we do this at the widenableBR, we can incorrectly ----
1180 // change a loop-invariant condition to a loop-varying one. ----
1181 auto *IP = cast(WidenableBR->getCondition()); 0
1182 ----
1183 // The use of umin(all analyzeable exits) instead of latch is subtle, but ----
1184 // important for profitability. We may have a loop which hasn't been fully ----
1185 // canonicalized just yet. If the exit we chose to widen is provably never ----
1186 // taken, we want the widened form to *also* be provably never taken. We ----
1187 // can't guarantee this as a current unanalyzeable exit may later become ----
1188 // analyzeable, but we can at least avoid the obvious cases. ----
1189 const SCEV *MinEC = getMinAnalyzeableBackedgeTakenCount(*SE, *DT, L); 0
1190 if (isa(MinEC) || MinEC->getType()->isPointerTy() || 0
1191 !SE->isLoopInvariant(MinEC, L) || 0
1192 !Rewriter.isSafeToExpandAt(MinEC, IP)) 0
1193 return ChangedLoop; 0
1194 ----
1195 Rewriter.setInsertPoint(IP); 0
1196 IRBuilder<> B(IP); 0
1197 ----
1198 bool InvalidateLoop = false; 0
1199 Value *MinECV = nullptr; // lazily generated if needed 0
1200 for (BasicBlock *ExitingBB : ExitingBlocks) { 0
1201 // If our exiting block exits multiple loops, we can only rewrite the ----
1202 // innermost one. Otherwise, we're changing how many times the innermost ----
1203 // loop runs before it exits. ----
1204 if (LI->getLoopFor(ExitingBB) != L) 0
1205 continue; 0
1206 ----
1207 // Can't rewrite non-branch yet. ----
1208 auto *BI = dyn_cast(ExitingBB->getTerminator()); 0
1209 if (!BI) 0
1210 continue; 0
1211 ----
1212 // If already constant, nothing to do. ----
1213 if (isa(BI->getCondition())) 0
1214 continue; 0
1215 ----
1216 const SCEV *ExitCount = SE->getExitCount(L, ExitingBB); 0
1217 if (isa(ExitCount) || 0
1218 ExitCount->getType()->isPointerTy() || 0
1219 !Rewriter.isSafeToExpandAt(ExitCount, WidenableBR)) 0
1220 continue; 0
1221 ----
1222 const bool ExitIfTrue = !L->contains(*succ_begin(ExitingBB)); 0
1223 BasicBlock *ExitBB = BI->getSuccessor(ExitIfTrue ? 0 : 1); 0
1224 if (!ExitBB->getPostdominatingDeoptimizeCall()) 0
1225 continue; 0
1226 ----
1227 /// Here we can be fairly sure that executing this exit will most likely ----
1228 /// lead to executing llvm.experimental.deoptimize. ----
1229 /// This is a profitability heuristic, not a legality constraint. ----
1230 ----
1231 // If we found a widenable exit condition, do two things: ----
1232 // 1) fold the widened exit test into the widenable condition ----
1233 // 2) fold the branch to untaken - avoids infinite looping ----
1234 ----
1235 Value *ECV = Rewriter.expandCodeFor(ExitCount); 0
1236 if (!MinECV) 0
1237 MinECV = Rewriter.expandCodeFor(MinEC); 0
1238 Value *RHS = MinECV; 0
1239 if (ECV->getType() != RHS->getType()) { 0
1240 Type *WiderTy = SE->getWiderType(ECV->getType(), RHS->getType()); 0
1241 ECV = B.CreateZExt(ECV, WiderTy); 0
1242 RHS = B.CreateZExt(RHS, WiderTy); 0
1243 } ----
1244 assert(!Latch || DT->dominates(ExitingBB, Latch)); 0
1245 Value *NewCond = B.CreateICmp(ICmpInst::ICMP_UGT, ECV, RHS); 0
1246 // Freeze poison or undef to an arbitrary bit pattern to ensure we can ----
1247 // branch without introducing UB. See NOTE ON POISON/UNDEF above for ----
1248 // context. ----
1249 NewCond = B.CreateFreeze(NewCond); 0
1250 ----
1251 widenWidenableBranch(WidenableBR, NewCond); 0
1252 ----
1253 Value *OldCond = BI->getCondition(); 0
1254 BI->setCondition(ConstantInt::get(OldCond->getType(), !ExitIfTrue)); 0
1255 InvalidateLoop = true; 0
1256 } ----
1257 ----
1258 if (InvalidateLoop) 0
1259 // We just mutated a bunch of loop exits changing there exit counts ----
1260 // widely. We need to force recomputation of the exit counts given these ----
1261 // changes. Note that all of the inserted exits are never taken, and ----
1262 // should be removed next time the CFG is modified. ----
1263 SE->forgetLoop(L); 0
1264 ----
1265 // Always return `true` since we have moved the WidenableBR's condition. ----
1266 return true; 0
1267 } 0
1268 ----
1269 bool LoopPredication::runOnLoop(Loop *Loop) { 0
1270 L = Loop; 0
1271 ----
1272 LLVM_DEBUG(dbgs() << "Analyzing "); 0
1273 LLVM_DEBUG(L->dump()); 0
1274 ----
1275 Module *M = L->getHeader()->getModule(); 0
1276 ----
1277 // There is nothing to do if the module doesn't use guards ----
1278 auto *GuardDecl = ----
1279 M->getFunction(Intrinsic::getName(Intrinsic::experimental_guard)); 0
1280 bool HasIntrinsicGuards = GuardDecl && !GuardDecl->use_empty(); 0
1281 auto *WCDecl = M->getFunction( 0
1282 Intrinsic::getName(Intrinsic::experimental_widenable_condition)); ----
1283 bool HasWidenableConditions = ----
1284 PredicateWidenableBranchGuards && WCDecl && !WCDecl->use_empty(); 0
1285 if (!HasIntrinsicGuards && !HasWidenableConditions) 0
1286 return false; 0
1287 ----
1288 DL = &M->getDataLayout(); 0
1289 ----
1290 Preheader = L->getLoopPreheader(); 0
1291 if (!Preheader) 0
1292 return false; 0
1293 ----
1294 auto LatchCheckOpt = parseLoopLatchICmp(); 0
1295 if (!LatchCheckOpt) 0
1296 return false; 0
1297 LatchCheck = *LatchCheckOpt; 0
1298 ----
1299 LLVM_DEBUG(dbgs() << "Latch check:\n"); 0
1300 LLVM_DEBUG(LatchCheck.dump()); 0
1301 ----
1302 if (!isLoopProfitableToPredicate()) { 0
1303 LLVM_DEBUG(dbgs() << "Loop not profitable to predicate!\n"); 0
1304 return false; 0
1305 } ----
1306 // Collect all the guards into a vector and process later, so as not ----
1307 // to invalidate the instruction iterator. ----
1308 SmallVector Guards; 0
1309 SmallVector GuardsAsWidenableBranches; 0
1310 for (const auto BB : L->blocks()) { 0
1311 for (auto &I : *BB) 0
1312 if (isGuard(&I)) 0
1313 Guards.push_back(cast(&I)); 0
1314 if (PredicateWidenableBranchGuards && 0
1315 isGuardAsWidenableBranch(BB->getTerminator())) 0
1316 GuardsAsWidenableBranches.push_back( 0
1317 cast(BB->getTerminator())); ----
1318 } ----
1319 ----
1320 SCEVExpander Expander(*SE, *DL, "loop-predication"); 0
1321 bool Changed = false; 0
1322 for (auto *Guard : Guards) 0
1323 Changed |= widenGuardConditions(Guard, Expander); 0
1324 for (auto *Guard : GuardsAsWidenableBranches) 0
1325 Changed |= widenWidenableBranchGuardConditions(Guard, Expander); 0
1326 Changed |= predicateLoopExits(L, Expander); 0
1327 ----
1328 if (MSSAU && VerifyMemorySSA) 0
1329 MSSAU->getMemorySSA()->verifyMemorySSA(); 0
1330 return Changed; 0
1331 } 0
1332 ----

9 // The LoopPredication pass tries to convert loop variant range checks to loop 9 // The LoopPredication pass tries to convert loop variant range checks to loop

40 // guard results in a circular logic where the guard is optimized under the 40 // guard results in a circular logic where the guard is optimized under the

94 // 94 //

96 // 96 //
97 // Note that we can use anything stronger than M, i.e. any condition which 97 // Note that we can use anything stronger than M, i.e. any condition which
98 // implies M. 98 // implies M.
99 // 99 //

148 // guardStart u< guardLimit && 148 // guardStart u< guardLimit &&

150 // For sle condition the widened condition is: 150 // For sle condition the widened condition is:
151 // guardStart u< guardLimit && 151 // guardStart u< guardLimit &&
152 // latchStart + guardLimit - 1 - guardStart s> latchLimit 152 // latchStart + guardLimit - 1 - guardStart s> latchLimit
153 // 153 //
154 // When S = -1 (i.e. reverse iterating loop), the transformation is supported 154 // When S = -1 (i.e. reverse iterating loop), the transformation is supported
155 // when: 155 // when:
156 // * The loop has a single latch with the condition of the form: 156 // * The loop has a single latch with the condition of the form:
157 // B(X) = X latchLimit, where is u>, u>=, s>, or s>=. 157 // B(X) = X latchLimit, where is u>, u>=, s>, or s>=.
158 // * The guard condition is of the form 158 // * The guard condition is of the form
159 // G(X) = X - 1 u< guardLimit 159 // G(X) = X - 1 u< guardLimit
160 // 160 //
161 // For the ugt latch comparison case M is: 161 // For the ugt latch comparison case M is:
162 // forall X. X-1 u< guardLimit and X u> latchLimit => X-2 u< guardLimit 162 // forall X. X-1 u< guardLimit and X u> latchLimit => X-2 u< guardLimit
163 // 163 //
164 // The only way the antecedent can be true and the consequent can be false is if 164 // The only way the antecedent can be true and the consequent can be false is if
165 // X == 1. 165 // X == 1.
166 // If X == 1 then the second half of the antecedent is 166 // If X == 1 then the second half of the antecedent is
167 // 1 u> latchLimit, and its negation is latchLimit u>= 1. 167 // 1 u> latchLimit, and its negation is latchLimit u>= 1.
168 // 168 //
169 // So the widened condition is: 169 // So the widened condition is:
170 // guardStart u< guardLimit && latchLimit u>= 1. 170 // guardStart u< guardLimit && latchLimit u>= 1.
171 // Similarly for sgt condition the widened condition is: 171 // Similarly for sgt condition the widened condition is:
172 // guardStart u< guardLimit && latchLimit s>= 1. 172 // guardStart u< guardLimit && latchLimit s>= 1.
173 // For uge condition the widened condition is: 173 // For uge condition the widened condition is:
174 // guardStart u< guardLimit && latchLimit u> 1. 174 // guardStart u< guardLimit && latchLimit u> 1.
175 // For sge condition the widened condition is: 175 // For sge condition the widened condition is:
176 // guardStart u< guardLimit && latchLimit s> 1. 176 // guardStart u< guardLimit && latchLimit s> 1.
177 //===----------------------------------------------------------------------===// 177 //===----------------------------------------------------------------------===//

389 std::optional LoopPredication::parseLoopICmp(ICmpInst *ICI) { 389 std::optional LoopPredication::parseLoopICmp(ICmpInst *ICI) {
390 auto Pred = ICI->getPredicate(); 390 auto Pred = ICI->getPredicate();
391 auto *LHS = ICI->getOperand(0); 391 auto *LHS = ICI->getOperand(0);
392 auto *RHS = ICI->getOperand(1); 392 auto *RHS = ICI->getOperand(1);
393 393
394 const SCEV *LHSS = SE->getSCEV(LHS); 394 const SCEV *LHSS = SE->getSCEV(LHS);
395 if (isa(LHSS)) 395 if (isa(LHSS))
396 return std::nullopt; 396 return std::nullopt;
397 const SCEV *RHSS = SE->getSCEV(RHS); 397 const SCEV *RHSS = SE->getSCEV(RHS);
398 if (isa(RHSS)) 398 if (isa(RHSS))
399 return std::nullopt; 399 return std::nullopt;
400 400
401 // Canonicalize RHS to be loop invariant bound, LHS - a loop computable IV 401 // Canonicalize RHS to be loop invariant bound, LHS - a loop computable IV
402 if (SE->isLoopInvariant(LHSS, L)) { 402 if (SE->isLoopInvariant(LHSS, L)) {
403 std::swap(LHS, RHS); 403 std::swap(LHS, RHS);
404 std::swap(LHSS, RHSS); 404 std::swap(LHSS, RHSS);
405 Pred = ICmpInst::getSwappedPredicate(Pred); 405 Pred = ICmpInst::getSwappedPredicate(Pred);
406 } 406 }
407 407
408 const SCEVAddRecExpr *AR = dyn_cast(LHSS); 408 const SCEVAddRecExpr *AR = dyn_cast(LHSS);
409 if (!AR || AR->getLoop() != L) 409 if (!AR || AR->getLoop() != L)
410 return std::nullopt; 410 return std::nullopt;
411 411
412 return LoopICmp(Pred, AR, RHSS); 412 return LoopICmp(Pred, AR, RHSS);
413 } 413 }

415 Value *LoopPredication::expandCheck(SCEVExpander &Expander, 415 Value *LoopPredication::expandCheck(SCEVExpander &Expander,
416 Instruction *Guard, 416 Instruction *Guard,
417 ICmpInst::Predicate Pred, const SCEV *LHS, 417 ICmpInst::Predicate Pred, const SCEV *LHS,
418 const SCEV *RHS) { 418 const SCEV *RHS) {
419 Type *Ty = LHS->getType(); 419 Type *Ty = LHS->getType();
420 assert(Ty == RHS->getType() && "expandCheck operands have different types?"); 420 assert(Ty == RHS->getType() && "expandCheck operands have different types?");
421 421
422 if (SE->isLoopInvariant(LHS, L) && SE->isLoopInvariant(RHS, L)) { 422 if (SE->isLoopInvariant(LHS, L) && SE->isLoopInvariant(RHS, L)) {
423 IRBuilder<> Builder(Guard); 423 IRBuilder<> Builder(Guard);
424 if (SE->isLoopEntryGuardedByCond(L, Pred, LHS, RHS)) 424 if (SE->isLoopEntryGuardedByCond(L, Pred, LHS, RHS))
425 return Builder.getTrue(); 425 return Builder.getTrue();
426 if (SE->isLoopEntryGuardedByCond(L, ICmpInst::getInversePredicate(Pred), 426 if (SE->isLoopEntryGuardedByCond(L, ICmpInst::getInversePredicate(Pred),
427 LHS, RHS)) 427 LHS, RHS))
428 return Builder.getFalse(); 428 return Builder.getFalse();
429 } 429 }
430 430
431 Value *LHSV = 431 Value *LHSV =
432 Expander.expandCodeFor(LHS, Ty, findInsertPt(Expander, Guard, {LHS})); 432 Expander.expandCodeFor(LHS, Ty, findInsertPt(Expander, Guard, {LHS}));
433 Value *RHSV = 433 Value *RHSV =
434 Expander.expandCodeFor(RHS, Ty, findInsertPt(Expander, Guard, {RHS})); 434 Expander.expandCodeFor(RHS, Ty, findInsertPt(Expander, Guard, {RHS}));
435 IRBuilder<> Builder(findInsertPt(Guard, {LHSV, RHSV})); 435 IRBuilder<> Builder(findInsertPt(Guard, {LHSV, RHSV}));
436 return Builder.CreateICmp(Pred, LHSV, RHSV); 436 return Builder.CreateICmp(Pred, LHSV, RHSV);
437 } 437 }

439 // Returns true if its safe to truncate the IV to RangeCheckType. 439 // Returns true if its safe to truncate the IV to RangeCheckType.
440 // When the IV type is wider than the range operand type, we can still do loop 440 // When the IV type is wider than the range operand type, we can still do loop
441 // predication, by generating SCEVs for the range and latch that are of the 441 // predication, by generating SCEVs for the range and latch that are of the
442 // same type. We achieve this by generating a SCEV truncate expression for the 442 // same type. We achieve this by generating a SCEV truncate expression for the
443 // latch IV. This is done iff truncation of the IV is a safe operation, 443 // latch IV. This is done iff truncation of the IV is a safe operation,
444 // without loss of information. 444 // without loss of information.
445 // Another way to achieve this is by generating a wider type SCEV for the 445 // Another way to achieve this is by generating a wider type SCEV for the
446 // range check operand, however, this needs a more involved check that 446 // range check operand, however, this needs a more involved check that
447 // operands do not overflow. This can lead to loss of information when the 447 // operands do not overflow. This can lead to loss of information when the
448 // range operand is of the form: add i32 %offset, %iv. We need to prove that 448 // range operand is of the form: add i32 %offset, %iv. We need to prove that
449 // sext(x + y) is same as sext(x) + sext(y). 449 // sext(x + y) is same as sext(x) + sext(y).
450 // This function returns true if we can safely represent the IV type in 450 // This function returns true if we can safely represent the IV type in
451 // the RangeCheckType without loss of information. 451 // the RangeCheckType without loss of information.
452 static bool isSafeToTruncateWideIVType(const DataLayout &DL, 452 static bool isSafeToTruncateWideIVType(const DataLayout &DL,
453 ScalarEvolution &SE, 453 ScalarEvolution &SE,
454 const LoopICmp LatchCheck, 454 const LoopICmp LatchCheck,
455 Type *RangeCheckType) { 455 Type *RangeCheckType) {
456 if (!EnableIVTruncation) 456 if (!EnableIVTruncation)
457 return false; 457 return false;
458 assert(DL.getTypeSizeInBits(LatchCheck.IV->getType()).getFixedValue() > 458 assert(DL.getTypeSizeInBits(LatchCheck.IV->getType()).getFixedValue() >
459 DL.getTypeSizeInBits(RangeCheckType).getFixedValue() && 459 DL.getTypeSizeInBits(RangeCheckType).getFixedValue() &&
460 "Expected latch check IV type to be larger than range check operand " 460 "Expected latch check IV type to be larger than range check operand "
461 "type!"); 461 "type!");
462 // The start and end values of the IV should be known. This is to guarantee 462 // The start and end values of the IV should be known. This is to guarantee
463 // that truncating the wide type will not lose information. 463 // that truncating the wide type will not lose information.
464 auto *Limit = dyn_cast(LatchCheck.Limit); 464 auto *Limit = dyn_cast(LatchCheck.Limit);
465 auto *Start = dyn_cast(LatchCheck.IV->getStart()); 465 auto *Start = dyn_cast(LatchCheck.IV->getStart());
466 if (!Limit || !Start) 466 if (!Limit || !Start)
467 return false; 467 return false;
468 // This check makes sure that the IV does not change sign during loop 468 // This check makes sure that the IV does not change sign during loop
469 // iterations. Consider latchType = i64, LatchStart = 5, Pred = ICMP_SGE, 469 // iterations. Consider latchType = i64, LatchStart = 5, Pred = ICMP_SGE,
470 // LatchEnd = 2, rangeCheckType = i32. If it's not a monotonic predicate, the 470 // LatchEnd = 2, rangeCheckType = i32. If it's not a monotonic predicate, the
471 // IV wraps around, and the truncation of the IV would lose the range of 471 // IV wraps around, and the truncation of the IV would lose the range of
472 // iterations between 2^32 and 2^64. 472 // iterations between 2^32 and 2^64.
473 if (!SE.getMonotonicPredicateType(LatchCheck.IV, LatchCheck.Pred)) 473 if (!SE.getMonotonicPredicateType(LatchCheck.IV, LatchCheck.Pred))
474 return false; 474 return false;
475 // The active bits should be less than the bits in the RangeCheckType. This 475 // The active bits should be less than the bits in the RangeCheckType. This
476 // guarantees that truncating the latch check to RangeCheckType is a safe 476 // guarantees that truncating the latch check to RangeCheckType is a safe
477 // operation. 477 // operation.
478 auto RangeCheckTypeBitSize = 478 auto RangeCheckTypeBitSize =
479 DL.getTypeSizeInBits(RangeCheckType).getFixedValue(); 479 DL.getTypeSizeInBits(RangeCheckType).getFixedValue();
480 return Start->getAPInt().getActiveBits() < RangeCheckTypeBitSize && 480 return Start->getAPInt().getActiveBits() < RangeCheckTypeBitSize &&
481 Limit->getAPInt().getActiveBits() < RangeCheckTypeBitSize; 481 Limit->getAPInt().getActiveBits() < RangeCheckTypeBitSize;
482 } 482 }
483 483
484 484
485 // Return an LoopICmp describing a latch check equivlent to LatchCheck but with 485 // Return an LoopICmp describing a latch check equivlent to LatchCheck but with
486 // the requested type if safe to do so. May involve the use of a new IV. 486 // the requested type if safe to do so. May involve the use of a new IV.
487 static std::optional generateLoopLatchCheck(const DataLayout &DL, 487 static std::optional generateLoopLatchCheck(const DataLayout &DL,
488 ScalarEvolution &SE, 488 ScalarEvolution &SE,
489 const LoopICmp LatchCheck, 489 const LoopICmp LatchCheck,
490 Type *RangeCheckType) { 490 Type *RangeCheckType) {
491 491
492 auto *LatchType = LatchCheck.IV->getType(); 492 auto *LatchType = LatchCheck.IV->getType();
493 if (RangeCheckType == LatchType) 493 if (RangeCheckType == LatchType)
494 return LatchCheck; 494 return LatchCheck;
495 // For now, bail out if latch type is narrower than range type. 495 // For now, bail out if latch type is narrower than range type.
496 if (DL.getTypeSizeInBits(LatchType).getFixedValue() < 496 if (DL.getTypeSizeInBits(LatchType).getFixedValue() <
497 DL.getTypeSizeInBits(RangeCheckType).getFixedValue()) 497 DL.getTypeSizeInBits(RangeCheckType).getFixedValue())
498 return std::nullopt; 498 return std::nullopt;
499 if (!isSafeToTruncateWideIVType(DL, SE, LatchCheck, RangeCheckType)) 499 if (!isSafeToTruncateWideIVType(DL, SE, LatchCheck, RangeCheckType))
500 return std::nullopt; 500 return std::nullopt;
501 // We can now safely identify the truncated version of the IV and limit for 501 // We can now safely identify the truncated version of the IV and limit for
502 // RangeCheckType. 502 // RangeCheckType.
503 LoopICmp NewLatchCheck; 503 LoopICmp NewLatchCheck;
504 NewLatchCheck.Pred = LatchCheck.Pred; 504 NewLatchCheck.Pred = LatchCheck.Pred;
505 NewLatchCheck.IV = dyn_cast( 505 NewLatchCheck.IV = dyn_cast(
506 SE.getTruncateExpr(LatchCheck.IV, RangeCheckType)); 506 SE.getTruncateExpr(LatchCheck.IV, RangeCheckType));
507 if (!NewLatchCheck.IV) 507 if (!NewLatchCheck.IV)
508 return std::nullopt; 508 return std::nullopt;
509 NewLatchCheck.Limit = SE.getTruncateExpr(LatchCheck.Limit, RangeCheckType); 509 NewLatchCheck.Limit = SE.getTruncateExpr(LatchCheck.Limit, RangeCheckType);
510 LLVM_DEBUG(dbgs() << "IV of type: " << *LatchType 510 LLVM_DEBUG(dbgs() << "IV of type: " << *LatchType
511 << "can be represented as range check type:" 511 << "can be represented as range check type:"
512 << *RangeCheckType << "\n"); 512 << *RangeCheckType << "\n");
513 LLVM_DEBUG(dbgs() << "LatchCheck.IV: " << *NewLatchCheck.IV << "\n"); 513 LLVM_DEBUG(dbgs() << "LatchCheck.IV: " << *NewLatchCheck.IV << "\n");
514 LLVM_DEBUG(dbgs() << "LatchCheck.Limit: " << *NewLatchCheck.Limit << "\n"); 514 LLVM_DEBUG(dbgs() << "LatchCheck.Limit: " << *NewLatchCheck.Limit << "\n");
515 return NewLatchCheck; 515 return NewLatchCheck;
516 } 516 }
517 517
518 bool LoopPredication::isSupportedStep(const SCEV* Step) { 518 bool LoopPredication::isSupportedStep(const SCEV* Step) {
519 return Step->isOne() || (Step->isAllOnesValue() && EnableCountDownLoop); 519 return Step->isOne() || (Step->isAllOnesValue() && EnableCountDownLoop);
520 } 520 }
521 521
522 Instruction *LoopPredication::findInsertPt(Instruction *Use, 522 Instruction *LoopPredication::findInsertPt(Instruction *Use,
523 ArrayRef Ops) { 523 ArrayRef Ops) {
524 for (Value *Op : Ops) 524 for (Value *Op : Ops)
525 if (!L->isLoopInvariant(Op)) 525 if (!L->isLoopInvariant(Op))
526 return Use; 526 return Use;
527 return Preheader->getTerminator(); 527 return Preheader->getTerminator();
528 } 528 }
529 529
530 Instruction *LoopPredication::findInsertPt(const SCEVExpander &Expander, 530 Instruction *LoopPredication::findInsertPt(const SCEVExpander &Expander,
531 Instruction *Use, 531 Instruction *Use,
532 ArrayRef Ops) { 532 ArrayRef Ops) {
533 // Subtlety: SCEV considers things to be invariant if the value produced is 533 // Subtlety: SCEV considers things to be invariant if the value produced is
534 // the same across iterations. This is not the same as being able to 534 // the same across iterations. This is not the same as being able to
535 // evaluate outside the loop, which is what we actually need here. 535 // evaluate outside the loop, which is what we actually need here.
536 for (const SCEV *Op : Ops) 536 for (const SCEV *Op : Ops)
537 if (!SE->isLoopInvariant(Op, L) || 537 if (!SE->isLoopInvariant(Op, L) ||
538 !Expander.isSafeToExpandAt(Op, Preheader->getTerminator())) 538 !Expander.isSafeToExpandAt(Op, Preheader->getTerminator()))
539 return Use; 539 return Use;
540 return Preheader->getTerminator(); 540 return Preheader->getTerminator();
541 } 541 }
542 542
543 bool LoopPredication::isLoopInvariantValue(const SCEV* S) { 543 bool LoopPredication::isLoopInvariantValue(const SCEV* S) {
544 // Handling expressions which produce invariant results, but *haven't* yet 544 // Handling expressions which produce invariant results, but *haven't* yet
545 // been removed from the loop serves two important purposes. 545 // been removed from the loop serves two important purposes.
546 // 1) Most importantly, it resolves a pass ordering cycle which would 546 // 1) Most importantly, it resolves a pass ordering cycle which would
547 // otherwise need us to iteration licm, loop-predication, and either 547 // otherwise need us to iteration licm, loop-predication, and either
548 // loop-unswitch or loop-peeling to make progress on examples with lots of 548 // loop-unswitch or loop-peeling to make progress on examples with lots of
549 // predicable range checks in a row. (Since, in the general case, we can't 549 // predicable range checks in a row. (Since, in the general case, we can't
550 // hoist the length checks until the dominating checks have been discharged 550 // hoist the length checks until the dominating checks have been discharged
551 // as we can't prove doing so is safe.) 551 // as we can't prove doing so is safe.)
552 // 2) As a nice side effect, this exposes the value of peeling or unswitching 552 // 2) As a nice side effect, this exposes the value of peeling or unswitching
553 // much more obviously in the IR. Otherwise, the cost modeling for other 553 // much more obviously in the IR. Otherwise, the cost modeling for other
554 // transforms would end up needing to duplicate all of this logic to model a 554 // transforms would end up needing to duplicate all of this logic to model a
555 // check which becomes predictable based on a modeled peel or unswitch. 555 // check which becomes predictable based on a modeled peel or unswitch.
556 // 556 //
557 // The cost of doing so in the worst case is an extra fill from the stack in 557 // The cost of doing so in the worst case is an extra fill from the stack in
558 // the loop to materialize the loop invariant test value instead of checking 558 // the loop to materialize the loop invariant test value instead of checking
559 // against the original IV which is presumable in a register inside the loop. 559 // against the original IV which is presumable in a register inside the loop.
560 // Such cases are presumably rare, and hint at missing oppurtunities for 560 // Such cases are presumably rare, and hint at missing oppurtunities for
561 // other passes. 561 // other passes.
562 562
563 if (SE->isLoopInvariant(S, L)) 563 if (SE->isLoopInvariant(S, L))
564 // Note: This the SCEV variant, so the original Value* may be within the 564 // Note: This the SCEV variant, so the original Value* may be within the
565 // loop even though SCEV has proven it is loop invariant. 565 // loop even though SCEV has proven it is loop invariant.
566 return true; 566 return true;
567 567
568 // Handle a particular important case which SCEV doesn't yet know about which 568 // Handle a particular important case which SCEV doesn't yet know about which
569 // shows up in range checks on arrays with immutable lengths. 569 // shows up in range checks on arrays with immutable lengths.
570 // TODO: This should be sunk inside SCEV. 570 // TODO: This should be sunk inside SCEV.
571 if (const SCEVUnknown *U = dyn_cast(S)) 571 if (const SCEVUnknown *U = dyn_cast(S))
572 if (const auto *LI = dyn_cast(U->getValue())) 572 if (const auto *LI = dyn_cast(U->getValue()))
573 if (LI->isUnordered() && L->hasLoopInvariantOperands(LI)) 573 if (LI->isUnordered() && L->hasLoopInvariantOperands(LI))
574 if (!isModSet(AA->getModRefInfoMask(LI->getOperand(0))) || 574 if (!isModSet(AA->getModRefInfoMask(LI->getOperand(0))) ||
575 LI->hasMetadata(LLVMContext::MD_invariant_load)) 575 LI->hasMetadata(LLVMContext::MD_invariant_load))
576 return true; 576 return true;
577 return false; 577 return false;
578 } 578 }
